summary: This is a declaration by Nicole McFarland, a BOP Staff Attorney, filed in support of the BOP's motion for summary judgment in a FOIA lawsuit brought by The New York Times. The declaration details the extensive searches conducted at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) for records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration, suicide attempt, and death, revealing that many key records (like SHU logs and video footage) had been handed over to investigative agencies.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's first reported suicide attempt while incarcerated at MCC, prompting his placement on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at MCC, an apparent suicide.

events.title: FBI Takes Custody of Video Footage
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation took custody of all video camera footage from MCC pertinent to Epstein's suicide and first suicide attempt.

events.title: OIG Takes Custody of SHU Logs
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) took custody of the Special Housing Unit (SHU) log books from MCC.

events.title: Recorded Visitor for Epstein
events.description: A visitor log book shows a visitor for Jeffrey Epstein on this date, which is after his death, indicating a record-keeping anomaly or posthumous administrative entry.

keyFacts: Key documentary evidence related to Epstein's incarceration and death—including SHU log books, visitor logs, and all video camera footage—had been handed over to the FBI and OIG by August 2019, and were not in BOP's possession during the FOIA search.
The search found no record of a formal meeting to decide to remove Jeffrey Epstein from suicide watch, according to the Executive Assistant to the MCC Warden and the MCC's chief psychologist.
No systematic log or recording of Epstein's phone calls from MCC was located, though some memoranda describing calls on legal lines were found.

The FOIA request sought a wide array of Epstein's prison records, including intake forms, housing history, disciplinary reports, medical reports, visitor lists, email lists, and call logs, highlighting the extent of public and media scrutiny into the circumstances of his death.
